text.headline: Findings of the Slavery in Northampton Research Project
Wenawen ordered to appear in court after breaking and entering
text.text: Wenawen was charged with breaking into Praisever Turner's Northampton mill. He was ordered to appear at court in Springfield  to answer to these charges, but he did not appear. There was a £3 bond for his appearance, which was paid local Native people who acted as guarantors for Wenawen: Chickwallop and Sophos. Chickwallop (also spelled Chickwalloppe) was a sachem of the Nonotuck, who would soon be named as the chief sachem when it came to the Nonotuck's dealings with both Massachusetts and Connecticut. Since no one appeared, the court declared the bond forfeited.

text.headline: Chickwallop and Sophos appear in court on Wenawen's behalf
text.text: Wenawen did not appear at the second court session where he was called to asnwer to charges of breaking and entering, but his gurantors, Chickwallop and Sophos, did appear. Praisever Turner testified that "he had lost from his mill by stealth divers tools & meal to the value of 30 pounds." At the time, this would have been the equivalent of 196 lbs of wheat. The court ruled that Wenawen, Chickwallop, and Sophos were responsible for paying either £40 or 20 fathoms of wampum to Turner "for his loss from his mill & for charges about this suit" (Judd manuscript, Hampshire Matters pt. 1, p. 33).

text.headline: Robin killed in a meadow
text.text: Robin, listed as "Indian servant to Nathaniel Clark," died. . Trumbull gives this account of Robin’s death: “...[he] was killed in the meadows...shot while riding his horse...About the same time many cattle and swine were destroyed in the meadows by the same party of Indians...Complaint was made to the General Court, and such forcible arguments brought to bear on the chiefs of the Mohawks, that within a couple of years the [Native people] made restitution for these unlawful acts. Twenty pounds of leather was placed in the custody of the County Court for this purpose. The amount as apportioned to those who suffered, in proportion to their loss. To Northampton £7 was awarded, viz. ‘ to the heirs of Nathaniel Clarke, for his Indian Servant, killed by said Magnaws, £3.10; to Joseph Parsons £1.10; and the rest 40s....The leather was placed in the hands of Simon Lobdell of Springfield, and he was to pay the award in shoes in ‘merchantable ware and reasonable prices.’” (Register of the deaths in Northampton; Trumbull, History of Northampton, Massachusetts)

text.headline: John Pynchon wrote a letter about an Native man
text.text: An Native man whose name we do not know was the subject of a letter from John Pynchon to John Winthrop Jr. during King Philip's War. The letter gives some details about his life. He lived in or near Northampton with a great deal of his family. He is also an interesting example of the divided loyalties during King Philip's War, since the entire letter is about the writer and all of the people around him questioning his loyalties. It also shows the hostility of the community toward this man.

text.headline: Pemequansett Born
text.text: Pemequansett was born around 1677. He was possibly the son or grandson of Umpanchela, a Native Sachem who lived in the Connecticut River Valley.

text.headline: Jack enslaved by Samuel Wolcott
text.text: Jack brought to Wethersfield, CT and enslaved by Samuel Wolcott. Samuel Wolcott was a violent man who was charged multiple times for acts of violence against his servants and even had an indentured servant named Hugh Peck removed from his custody by the court. Wolcott treated Jack in a similar manner, as Jack would later state that Wolcott "always beates him sometimes with 100 blows" and stated that the effects of these beatings were so brutal that "he hath told his Master that he would sometimes of other hang himself." (Account book of Samuel Wolcott; Pynchon Court Record)

text.headline: Caleb died
text.text: Caleb died. Little is known about Caleb other than the fact that he was an Native man, potentially employed or indentured by Joshua Henshaw (Massachusetts Vital Records)

text.headline: Jack took his freedom
text.text: Jack took his freedom from Samuel Wolcott. At some point in the next week, he made his way through Southfield and stole a gun. Later that week or the next, he came to the home of Anthony Dorchester (probably in Springfield) and asked for tobacco. He then stole the knife used to cut the tobacco, grabbed a cutlass in the home, and threatened Dorchester with it. Dorchcester was able to grab Jack and his family helped tie Jack up. Once tied up, Dorchester found the knife he had stolen.

text.headline: Jack was jailed
text.text: Jack was jailed for threatening Anthony Dorchester on July 1. Some historians state that he escaped from prison, but it cannot be explicitly confirmed (Pynchon Court Record)

text.headline: Jack started a fire at William Clark's house
text.text: Jack started the fire that burned William Clark's house. He ran but was caught and confessed. He stated that the fire was unintentional, but even arson with no fatalities could be a capital offense. He pleaded not guilty, but was found guilty (Pynchon Court Record).

text.headline: Jack was executed
text.text: Jack was hanged in Boston, and then burned with another woman of color named Maria convicted of arson (Pynchon Court Record).

text.headline: Mingo and Hannah charged and tried for fornication
text.text: Mingo (enslaved by Samuel Parsons) and Hannah (enslaved by Timothy Baker) were charged and tried for fornication. The court notes state that "she owned the fact [that she was guilty] and accused Mingo as the father of her child in open court." They were sentenced to 15 lashes on their naked bodies. Since both Mingo and Hannah were enslaved, their child would be born into slavery. The child would belong to both Parsons and Baker until the child was nine years old. Then, either Parsons or Baker would pay the other half the value that they assigned to the child and take full ownership or continue joint property of the child (Judd Manuscript).

text.headline: Richard Church is killed
text.text: Richard Church was killed while hunting in the woods by Mount Warner near sunset. Four Native men, Mowenas, Moquolas, Pemequenoxet, and Wenepuck were later charged with the crime.

text.headline: Mowenas, Moquolas, Pemequenoxet, and Wenepuck are arrested
text.text: The four men were arrested along with other Native people from the Hatgield Schaghticoke community, including eight men, nine women, and 23 children.

text.headline: Mowenas and Moquolas charged with murder
text.text: Mowenas and Moquolas, also known as Strawberry's son, were charged with murder on October 21, 1696.

text.headline: Mowenas and Moquolas executed
text.text: Mowenas and Moquolas were both executed on October 23, 1696.

text.headline: Ishmael in Northampton
text.text: Ishmael was included in the Judd Manuscript as "Ishmael Negro", but little else is known about him. We know he was a late adolescent or adult in 1714, when his child was born. He was married Johanah and their child was named Peter.

text.headline: Peter born
text.text: Peter born. He is listed as the son of Ishmael and Johanah (Genealogy Record, Judd Manuscript)

text.headline: Bathsheba Hull born
text.text: Bathsheba Hull was considered a "girl" in the mid 1740s, which probably means she was born at some point in the 1720s.

text.headline: Venus born in West Africa
text.text: Venus was likely born in West Africa at this time (Minkema, Jonathan Edwards' Defense of Slavery)

text.headline: Abijah Prince enslaved by Doolittle family
text.text: Prince was enslaved by Rev. Benjamin Doolittle and his wife Lydia Todd who first lived in Wallingford, CT and then moved to Northfield, MA. Prince knew how to read and write and was taught other skills (Holbrook Gerzina, Mr. and Mrs. Prince)

text.headline: Elizabeth Maminash Born
text.text: Based on her age at the time of her death, it seems that Elizabeth Maminash was born in or close to 1719. She was a Mohegan woman, and the sister of the famous Native minister Sampson Occum.

text.headline: Tony born and enslaved
text.text: Tony born. At some point, he was enslaved by Ezra Clapp in Westfield, MA, and then got his freedom ("Uncovering the Stories of Black Families in Springfield and Hampden County, Massachusetts, 1650-1865" in Historical Journal of Western Massachusetts, Westfield State University).

text.headline: Nanne listed in a probate record
text.text: Nanne (also spelled Nanny) was listed as "Negro girl" in 1723 probate record of Benjamin Lyman. Nanne is probably a nickname, suggesting her full name may have been Ann or Anne (Hampshire County Probate Records).

text.headline: Mingo listed in Samuel Parsons' will
text.text: Mingo was listed in Samuel Parsons' will. Parsons asked that his four sons "shall Take care of...my Aged Nego Man Named Mingo & his wife." Mingo was likely enslaved by Parsons for much of his life (The Parsons Family: Descendants of Cornet Joseph Parsons, compiled by Gerald James Parsons)

text.headline: Coffee listed in Samuel Marshall's will
text.text: Coffee was listed as a "servant" in his enslaver Samuel Marshall's will. Marshall left Coffee to his daughters with the instructions to sell him and divide the profits.

text.headline: Boston listed in Ebenezer Strong's will
text.text: Boston (who also went by the name George) listed as an "indian slave" in Ebenezer Strong's 1729 will.

text.headline: A Black person listed in John Lancton's will
text.text: A Black person whose name we do not know was listed as a "negro servant" and enslaved by John Lancton/Langton, listed in Lancton's 1728 probate record. The record stated their value at £60.

text.headline: A male child listed in the inventory of Ebenezer Strong
text.text: A Black male child whose name we do not know was listed in the inventory of the estate of Ebenezer Strong in 1729. This inventory recorded him with the value of £80.

text.headline: Venus was enslaved by Jonathan Edwards
text.text: Venus was enslaved by Jonathan Edwards at fourteen years old. She was the first person Edwards enslaved. Edwards paid 80 pounds to Richard Perkins in Newport, RI to enslave Venus. The only reason that we know about this sale is that Edwards used the receipt for Venus as scrap paper, and kept the notes that he wrote on the back of it. Since no one has yet found documentation of Venus after the sale, Kenneth Minkema has posited that she and Leah may have been the same person (Minkema, Jonathan Edwards's Defense of Slavery).

text.headline: Rose Binney born
text.text: Rose Binney was born, possibly in West Africa (Jones, Stockbridge, Past and Present)

text.headline: Jonah baptized
text.text: Jonah was baptized. His baptism record lists him as "Jonah Negro", a "negro servant to Maj. Pomeroy," referring to Ebenezer Pomeroy (First Churches Records)

text.headline: Jesse baptized
text.text: Jesse was baptized. He was a servant to Major Pomeroy, or Ebenezer Pomeroy (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Josie baptized
text.text: Josie was baptized. She was listed as a "servant" to Major Ebenezer Pomeroy (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Elizabeth baptized
text.text: Elizabeth was baptized. She was enslaved by Colonel John Stoddard and a member of the Church of Christ in Northampton (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Simon baptized
text.text: Simon was baptized. He was probably ensalved by Captain Timothy Dwight II, as his baptism record referred to him as a "servant to Captain Dwight" (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Leah baptized
text.text: Leah was baptized. She was enslaved by Jonathan Edwards and his wife Sarah Pierrepoint Edwards. She was a full member of the First Church of Christ in Northampton (First Churches Records). Kenneth Minkema has posited that Leah and Venus may have been the same person.

text.headline: Ishmael baptized
text.text: Ishmael was baptized. He was a "servant" to Nathan Edwards (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Josie treated by Dr. Crouch
text.text: Dr. Crouch treated Josie with pills, mercury plaster, and lignum vitae. Josie was enslaved by Ebenezer Pomeroy (Judd Manuscript).

text.headline: Josie continued to be treated by Dr. Crouch
text.text: Dr. Crouch visited Josie visited 27. He gave her more lignum vitae and recorded "began her salivation." She may have been beginning to salivate as a side effect of being treated with mercury or by the doctor attempting to induce excessive salivation by other means (Judd Manuscipt).

text.headline: Dorothy baptized
text.text: Dorothy was baptized. She enslaved by Benjamin Stebbins. It is possible she is the Dorothy who was married to Jonah in 1739, making her the mother of at least two sons, both named Felix (one died soon after birth) born in 1739 and 1740 (First Churches Records; Northampton, Massachusetts Marriages)

text.headline: Dinah baptized
text.text: Dinah was baptized. Dinah was enslaved by Joseph and Mercy Bartlett (First Churches Records)

text.headline: Dorothy and Jonah married
text.text: Marriage records of Dorothy and Jonah were dated March 12, 1739. It is likely that this Dorothy was enslaved by Benjamin Stebbins. Jonah was enslaved by Major Ebenezer Pomeroy.

text.headline: Felix baptized and later died in infancy
text.text: Felix was baptized. He was listed as the son of "Jonah Negro" in his baptismal record, so he was most likely the son of Jonah and Dorothy. He likely died in infancy, as his brother was also named Felix. At the time it was common practice for a family who lost a child to give the same name to their next child of the same sex (First Churches Records)

text.headline: Amos Hull Sr. becomes a member of the First Church of Christ
text.text: The First Church of Christ Records list Amos Hull Sr. as a member and as a “Servant” of Jonathan Hunt III, which indicates that Hunt enslaved him. The membership roll is not dated, but it means that Hull became a member during Jonathan Edwards' ministry. At some point during this period, Amos Hull Sr. was a slave.

text.headline: Felix baptized
text.text: Felix was baptized. He was the second to have this name in his family, as his older brother who died was also named Felix. Jonah was his father, and Dorothy was likely his mother (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Jason becomes a member of the First church of Christ
text.text: Jason was enslaved by Ebenezer Pomeroy, the gunsmith and tavern owner. He became a member of the First Church during Jonathan Edwards' ministry.  (Historical Catalogue of Northampton's First Church)

text.headline: Rose Binney captured
text.text: Rose Binney captured "when a child...as she was getting water from a spring", as told by Electa Jones in Stockbridge, Past and Present, a 19th century history of Stockbridge. This story might be apocryphal.

text.headline: Rose Binney enslaved by Jonathan Edwards and began relationship with Joab Binney
text.text: Rose Binney was enslaved by Jonathan Edwards in Northampton, MA during the 1740s. At some point during this period she began a relationship with Joab Binney. The timing for both of these events is not exact.

text.headline: Moidore enslaved by Lt. Caleb Strong Sr.
text.text: Moidore (also known as Midah) was enslaved by Lt. Caleb Strong Sr. He was known as an accomplished fiddler and worked in Strong's tannery (Judd Manuscript; Rozwenc, The Northampton Book). The exact dates of his enslavement are unknown (one source simply refers to it as "before the Revolution), and he may have later been freed and transitioned to a paid employee of Strong.

text.headline: Joab Binney enslaved by Jonathan Hunt III
text.text: Joab Binney, originally from Africa (country unknown), was enslaved by Jonathan Hunt III. It is also possible he was enslaved by a member of the Strong family (Northampton Town Papers).

text.headline: Joab baptized
text.text: Joab was baptized and listed as the "negro servant" to Mrs. Strong. This could be Joab Binney, but we do not have enough evidence to be confident (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Bathsheba Hull testified in the "bad book" case
text.text: A woman called "Bathsheba Negro," who may have been Bathsheba Hull testified in Jonathan Edwards’ investigation of the “bad book” episode. Edwards accused several white young men and boys of reading lewd material, possibly a midwifery text. Bathsheba testified that Noah Baker, Timothy Warner, and Elkanah Burt read the book aloud to her and Naomi Warner. The accused may have assaulted Bathsheba and Warner but that is unclear in the text (Documents Relating to the “Bad Book” Case, Church and Pastoral Documents (WJE Online, vol. 39.), ed. Jonathan Edwards Center).

text.headline: Joseph Maminash I mustered for the English campaign against Louisbourg
text.text: When Mohegan men from Connecticut were recruited for the English campaign against Louisbourg in 1745, Joseph Maminash I (identified in colonial records as Podunk, Nonotuck, and/or Pocumtuck) joined Nathan Whiting’s 11th company, along with a number of Indian men in this and related companies, including members of the Uncas, Dick, Nanapau, Quaquequid and Wetowomp families (Whiting 1745).

text.headline: Pompy left to Samuel Clark's son in Clark's will
text.text: Pompy was enslaved by Samuel Clark. Clark left Pompy to his son in his will. Pompy may have died in 1746, but that record refers to an Native person and this one appears to refer to a Black person, so either they were different people or Pompy was mixed race.

text.headline: Pompey died
text.text: Pompey, who may have been the same man enslaved by Samuel Clark, died. In one Northampton register, he is listed as "an Indian." (Register of the deaths in Northampton)

text.headline: Abijah Prince enslisted in army and gained freedom
text.text: Abijah Prince enlisted in Captain Elijah Williams’ company in Deerfield to fight in King George’s War. Gretchen Holbrook Gerzina believes that before enlisting, Prince had arranged for a man named Aaron Burt to purchase him, with the understanding that Prince would be freed, either by paying his military salary to him or some other agreement. Burt did grant Prince his freedom (Holbrook Gerzina, Mr. and Mrs. Prince)

text.headline: Elizabeth enslaved by Prudence Stoddard
text.text: Elizabeth was enslaved by Prudence Stoddard after John Stoddard's death. Elizabeth was listed as a "Negro maid" among his property. The probate record (made 10 years after Stoddard's death) listed her value as 80 pounds (John Stoddard Probate Record).

text.headline: Ebenezer Hunt purchases a hat for Moidore
text.text: The accounts of Ebenezer Hunt list Caleb Strong purchasing a "castor hat" for "His negro Moidore." This would refer to a hat that was made of wool, or a mixture of wool and fur, such as rabbit fur (Judd manuscript, Northampton MA Prices and Account Books, p. 32).

text.headline: Rose Binney gained her freedom
text.text: The exact date when Rose Binney gained her freedom from Jonathan Edwards is unclear. She was not accounted for in the valuations of his property in 1753 and did not move with Edwards when he left Stockbridge, which suggests that she was free before that time.

text.headline: Joab Binney gained his freedom
text.text: Joab Binney gained his freedom in the early 1750s, but both the exact date and the method by which he gained his freedom are unclear. It is possible that Binney bought his freedom from the wages he may have earned in skilled trades. There is also a story, perhaps apocryphal, that Jonathan Hunt III, Binney's enslaver, was angry with Jonahtan Edwards and granted Binney freedom so that he could remain with Rose Binney in Stockbridge, therefore cutting ties between the Hunt family and Edwards (Jones, Stockbridge, Past and Present)

text.headline: Amos Hull Sr. was enslaved in Northampton
text.text: Amos Hull Sr. was enslaved in Northampton at some point during these years. His enslaved status is uncertain: in the First Churches Records, he is listed as a "servant" of Jonathan Hunt III (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Rose Binney moved to Stockbridge with Edwards
text.text: Rose Binney moved to Stockbridge with Edwards and his household after Jonathan Edwards was removed from his position as minister (Jones, Stockbridge, Past and Present)

text.headline: Rose and Joab Binney married
text.text: Rose and Joab Binney were married, possibly by Jonathan Edwards. Though marriage was often conducted through the state in colonial Massachusetts, by the beginning of the 18th century it was often performed by a minister (Minkema, Jonathan Edwards' Defense of Slavery)

text.headline: Bathsheba Hull Gained her Freedom and Stayed in Northampton
text.text: Bathsheba Hull lived in Northampton as a free woman at some point during this period, though we do not know when or how she gained her freedom. She lived in a home near present-day West Street. We do not know the full details of her profession, but we do know that at least on one occasion, she took in laundry for Ebenezer Hunt (Judd Manuscript; Trumbull, History of Northampton, Massachusetts).

text.headline: Bathsheba Hull Purchases Land in the Mill River Trench
text.text: When widowed (after 1761), Bathsheba Hull bought a house and land from John McLane on an island formed by the Mill River Trench. The Trench was the route that waste water from the town's original mill took to get back to the Mill River. The Trench was hard on the land surrounding it and Bathsheba would have had to deal with soil erosion, flooding, and difficulties entering and exiting the island (Judd Manuscript; Trumbull, History of Northampton, Massachusetts)

text.headline: Joab Binney lived and worked in Stockbridge
text.text: Joab Binney lived in Stockbridge and made a living either as a tanner or a blacksmith. He owned a 10.5 acre farm and had numerous livestock and crops (Stockbridge Property Valuation)

text.headline: Abijah Prince in Lived in Northampton
text.text: Abijah Prince lived in Northampton for two years. He worked for church deacon and hatter Ebenezer Hunt and lived with Amos Hull, also a formerly enslaved man, and his wife Bathsheba.

text.headline: A person whose name we do not know was enslaved by Preserved Bartlett
text.text: An person whose name we do not know was enslaved by Preserved Bartlett and listed in 1752 Northampton tax records (Northampton Town Papers).

text.headline: A person whose name we do not know was enslaved by John Stoddard
text.text: A person whose name we do not know was enslaved by Major Jonathan Stoddard and listed in 1752 Northampton tax records (Northampton Town Papers).

text.headline: Amos Hull Jr. born and baptized
text.text: Amos Hull Jr. born to Bathsheba and Amos Hull Sr. and baptized Sept. 15, 1754 (First Churches Records)

text.headline: Peter Gets His Freedom
text.text: Joseph Bartlett freed Peter in his will of 1754, and so Peter would have been free on Bartlett's death in 1755. Peter kept working for Mercy Bartlett, Joseph Bartlett's widow, up until her death in 1759 (Probate record of Joseph Bartlett).

text.headline: Peter Ladue served in the Fourth French and Indian War
text.text: Peter Ladue listed as serving in the company commanded by Captain Elisha Hawley in what was at the time called the Fourth French and Indian War (Trumbull, History of Northampton, Massachusetts).

text.headline: Pamphlet published About Jack's Arson Charge
text.text: A pamphlet was published detailing the crimes Jack was convicted of, with particular emphasis on the fire at the Clark house. This pamphlet described Jack as "Instigated by the Divill", portraying him as a vicious man who purposefully set fire to the house (Trumbull, History of Northampton, Massachusetts).

text.headline: Dinah Gets Her Freedom
text.text: Dinah was given her freedom in Joseph Bartlett's 1754 will, and so gained that freedom when he died in 1755. He also left her four pounds, to be paid two years after his death, if she was not married. If she was married, she would receive the equivalent of four pounds and thirteen shillings in household items on her wedding day. This could mean that she was of a common marrying age at the time (late teens or twenties, which would mean that the Bartletts had enslaved her as a child) or was in a relationship that made the Bartletts anticipate her upcoming marriage (Probate Record of Joseph Bartlett).

text.headline: Asaph Hull born and baptized
text.text: Asaph Hull born to Amos Sr. and Bathsheba Hull. He was baptized November 23 (First Churches Records).

text.headline: A person whose name we do not know was enslaved by Samuel Mather
text.text: A person whose name we do not know was enslaved by Samuel Mather, a doctor. This person was listed in the 1756 Northampton tax records.

text.headline: A person whose name we do not know was enslaved by Caleb Strong
text.text: Northampton tax records listed Caleb Strong as enslaving one person, but did not list the name of the person. This may have been Moidore. He was also probaby listed in the 1764 town census but not named (Trumbull, History of Northampton, Massachusetts; Northampton Town Papers)

text.headline: Sylvia Church born
text.text: Sylvia Church was born in or near 1756. This information is from her gravestone, so the birth year is not exact.

text.headline: Abijah Prince married and established a life in Guilford, VT
text.text: Abijah Prince met Lucy Terry and the two married on May 17, 1756. They eventually moved to Guilford, VT and established a farm there. They had six children between the years of 1757 and 1769. While in Guilford, the Princes endured many racist attacks from their neighbors, particularly from the Noyes family and their social network. One man assaulted two of the Prince children with sticks while another destroyed trees and fences and set farm animals loose on the Princes’ property to decimate their crops and force them off their land.

text.headline: Jack died
text.text: Jack died in Northampton in 1757. He was listed as a "negro servant" which was often a way of referring to enslaved people, but no other information was given (Register of the deaths in Northampton).

text.headline: Margaret Hull I baptized
text.text: Margaret Hull was baptized. She was the third child of Amos and Bathsheba Hull (Judd manuscript).

text.headline: Margaret Hull I died
text.text: Margaret died as an infant or young child on Dec. 24, 1757 (First Churches Records; Judd Manuscript).

text.headline: Agrippa Hull born
text.text: Agrippa Hull was born, the son of Bathsheba and Amos Hull. He was their fifth child.

text.headline: Mercy Bartlett died and left Dinah household items
text.text: Mercy Bartlett died and in her will, left Dinah many household items including a stallion, kitchen utensils, spinning wheel, and furniture. This grouping of items could indicate the type of work Dinah did in the Bartlett house. She was also left books, suggesting that Dinah knew how to read. Though there were some places in the country where teaching an enslaved person to read was illegal, it was legal in Massachusetts at this point.

text.headline: Mercy Bartlett died and left Peter household items
text.text: In her will, Mercy Bartlett left Peter the bed he slept on, furniture, farm animals, and tools. This could indicate that Peter was doing farm and caretaker work for the Bartletts. Additionally, the listing of objects in the will suggest that Peter may have slept in the barn or another outbuilding that housed animals.

text.headline: Margaret Hull II baptized
text.text: Margaret Hull was baptized. She was the fifth child of Amos and Bethsheba Hull. She was the second Hull child named Margaret, as it was customary for families who had lost a child to name the next child of the same sex the name of the child who had passed away (Judd Manuscript).

text.headline: Amos Hull Sr. died
text.text: Amos Hull Sr. died. A valuation of his property noted that he owned two horses and a cow, valued at 5 pounds, 10 shillings (First Churches Records; Judd Manuscript).

text.headline: Bathsheba married her second husband, Philemon Lee
text.text: At some point between 1761 (when Amos died) and 1768, Bathsheba married her second husband, Philemon Lee. We do not know the exact date as we have not seen a record of the marriage, but in 1768, she is referred to as Lee's wife.

text.headline: Rose and Joab Binney had five children in Stockbridge
text.text: Rose and Joab Binney had four daugters who died in infancy and one daughter who lived, named Tamar All were born in Stockbridge (Jones, Stockbridge, Past and Present).

text.headline: Asaph Hull placed as an indentured servant
text.text: Asaph Hull placed as an indentured servant in Fairfield, CT, with Seth Pomeroy, son of the gunsmith and soldier. He may have been placed there without Bathsheba's approval, since she is not mentioned in the documentation at all. His father died in 1761, so Bathsheba being a single parent and a woman of color could have played heavily into the town's decision to remove him from his home.

text.headline: A Woman Named Dinah lived in Moses Kingsley's House
text.text: Sylvester Judd wrote that "there seems to be a Dinah also at Moses Kingsley's - not a slave". Dinah is a common name for women of color at this time, so this may or may not be the same Dinah enslaved by the Bartletts, but it is possible that after Mercy Bartlett's death, she went to live or work in the home of Moses Kingsley (Judd Manuscript).

text.headline: A person was enslaved by Jonathan Clapp
text.text: A person whose name we do not know was enslaved by Jonathan Clapp, a miller and tavern owner, and listed in the 1764 Northampton census.

text.headline: A person was enslaved by Joseph Clapp
text.text: A person whose name we do not know was enslaved by Joseph Clapp and listed in the 1764 Northampton census.

text.headline: A man was enslaved by Joseph Hunt
text.text: A man whose name we do not know was enslaved by Joseph Hunt and listed in the 1764 Northampton census. This may be the same person who was also listed in 1759 Northampton tax records, but no gender is known for the person in that entry.

text.headline: A woman was enslaved by Joseph Hunt
text.text: A woman whose name we do not know was enslaved by Joseph Hunt and listed in the 1764 Northampton census.

text.headline: A free person of color was listed in Northampton census
text.text: A free person of color whose name we do not know was listed in the 1764 Northampton census. This person lived in the home of Moses Kingsley. This may be Dinah - but since there is no name or gender listed, it has its own entry.

text.headline: A person of color listed in Northampton census
text.text: A person of color whose name we do not know was listed in the 1764 Northampton census. This person lived in the home of Zadoc Danks and it is unclear whether this person was enslaved or free.

text.headline: Sally Maminash born
text.text: Sally Maminash was born to Joseph Maminash I and Elizabeth Maminash. Elizabeth was Mohegan and Joseph was Nonotuck and Podunk.

text.headline: Cato worked in a lead mine
text.text: Cato brought to Northampton by several men from Roxbury, CT to work in a lead mine about 6 miles from Northampton (Trumbull, History of Northampton, Massachusetts).

text.headline: Cesar worked in a lead mine
text.text: Cesar brought to Northampton by several men from Roxbury, CT to work in a lead mine about 6 miles from Northampton (Trumbull, History of Northampton, Massachusetts).

text.headline: Tom worked in a lead mine
text.text: Tom brought to Northampton by several men from Roxbury, CT to work in a lead mine about 6 miles from Northampton (Trumbull, History of Northampton, Massachusetts).

text.headline: Northampton seized Bathsheba Hull's land
text.text: The town of Northampton claimed rights to the land Bathsheba Hull was living on and forced her to either sell her land or have her house demolished. It seems that she did sell, as the town moved her belongings to the lower end of Pleasant St. in 1768. The reason given for  seizing her land was that the father of the man who sold Hull the land was squatting on it and had no legitimate claim. However, it is worth noting that the town had not tried to seize it while two generations of white men owned the property, despite them having the same ownership rights (Judd Manuscript; Trumbull, History of Northampton, Massachusetts).

text.headline: Agrippa Hull fostered by the Binneys
text.text: Agrippa Hull was fostered by Joab and Rose Binney in Stockbridge, MA after his mother was evicted from her home in Northampton in 1765. It seems that Hull kept up a relationship with the Binneys later in his life.

text.headline: Amos Hull Jr. possibly placed in Hadley
text.text: Amos Hull Jr. possibly placed in Hadley after his mother forced off her land. There is a record for an Amos Hull from Hadley who served in several regiments during the American Revolution and deserted either once or twice. He served between 1776 and 1780 (Massachusetts Soldiers and Sailors of the Revolutionary War)

text.headline: Phillis born
text.text: Phillis born. She was the daughter of Peg and was enslaved by the Phelps family in Hadley. Peg was later sold away from Phillis in order to marry the man she chose (Miller, Entangled Lives).

text.headline: Medford listed in records
text.text: Medford listed as a "free negro" in First Churches records. This date may either be a baptism date or a death date (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Asaph Hull died at age 10
text.text: Asaph Hull died in Connecticut, cause unknkown. He was 10 years old (Northampton Overseers of the Poor Records).

text.headline: Warrant filed to warn Philemon Lee out of Northampton
text.text: A warrant was filed to warn Philemon Lee out of Northampton. Warnings out or cautions were deviced in which the board of selectmen controlled residency in the location the selectment administered. In the ruling, the selectmen were not required to give a reason for the caution and often did not, but the purpose of warnings out were generally to remove non-residents who required public support due to their economic circumstances. Besides economic reasons, a person could be warned out if neighbors complained about their behavior, opening the doors for already marginalized people to be expelled from New England towns. Even people of color who were lawful residents of New England town were unofficially warned out (Hampshire Council of Government Records; Wallis Herndon, Unwelcome Americans: Living on the Margin in Early New England)

text.headline: Joseph Maminash I died
text.text: When he died in 1767, Maminash was buried on the site that is now called “Hospital Hill,” for the mental hospital that was built there in the 1880s. His grave was marked with a brown stone bearing the mark of the turtle, the clan totem of the family.

text.headline: Philemon Lee removed by town
text.text: Philemon Lee refused to leave Northampton and was then removed by the town and taken back to Simsbury, CT (Hampshire Council of Government Records).

text.headline: Philemon Lee returned to Northampton
text.text: Philemon Lee returned to Northampton. The selectmen of the town convened legal proceedings against him again (Hampshire Council of Government Records).

text.headline: Philemon Lee jailed in Springfield
text.text: Philemon Lee sent to jail in Springfield. He was held for one week and released on August 25th. He was released with a promise that he would never return to Northampton (Hampshire Council of Government Records).

text.headline: Philemon Lee returned to Northampton
text.text: Philemon Lee returned to Northampton. The selectmen of the town convened legal proceedings against him once again. During these proceedings, Lee expressed "a Design and an Intention of obtaining an estate in Land in the Said Town of Northampton." Lee may have been warned out due to racial motivations, if Lee had the funds to buy land in Northampton, which would have made him a legal resident (Hampshire Council of Government Records).

text.headline: Philemon Lee Jailed in Springfield Again
text.text: Lee was removed from Northampton and sent to jail in Springfield on November 10, 1767. This appears to have been a much longer imprisonment. He was released from jail the following May and again promised not to return to Northampton. As far as we know, he did not return. Since Bathsheba Hull and her daughter relocated to Springfield in the month Lee was released, they may have moved to meet him and start their lives in a new place (History of Northampton, Massachusetts; Judd Manuscript).

text.headline: Bess died
text.text: Bess died on October 13, 1767, cause unknown. This may be the same person enslaved by Colonel John Stoddard, referred to as Elizabeth and Bes, but Elizabeth was also a common name for the time, so we cannot be sure (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Robert Entered the Phelps House
text.text: Robert would later be accused of breaking and entering into the "mansion house" of Charles Phelps in Hadley on October 24, 1767. In the house were Charles Phelps Jr., Dorothy Phelps, and Abigail Phelps. The charge stated that Robert entered the house "with intent to commit fornication with and have carnal knowledge of the body of the said Dorothy and the said Abigail" (Hampshire Council of Governments Records).

text.headline: Robert Entered the Strickland House
text.text: Robert would later be accused of breaking and entering into John Strickland's house in Hadley on October 25, 1767. Also in residence were John Clark, his wife (unnamed in the record), and his daughter Mary Clark. Robert was accused of "being in the same house with the intent to commit fornication with and have carnal knowledge of the said Mary Clark then being in Bed in the same house." He was later tried in Northampton (Hampshire Council of Governments Records)

text.headline: Robert Tried for Breaking and Entering
text.text: Robert was tried twice in the Inferior Court in Northampton for charges of breaking and entering. Robert was a laborer by profession who lived in Hadley, MA. By the time of the trial, Robert had been imprisoned in Springfield, but was brought to Northampton for the trial and prosecuted by John Worthington, the King's council. In both cases, Robert said that he would "not contend", which appears to mean that he would not contest the charges. He was sentenced to be whipped ten lashes for each offense and pay £3 17s 11p for the first offense and £3 10s 11p for the second, considerable costs for the time. With a court record that includes so little testimony, it can be hard to tell the details of the trial or the proof presented with regard to the accusations (Hampshire Council of Government Records).

text.headline: Bathsheba and Margaret Hull warned out of Springfield
text.text: In May of 1768, Bathsheba and Margaret Hull moved to Springfield. Since they were not residents of Springfield, they were vulnerable to being warned out. After Philemon Lee was released from jail, the local government did just that. After they left Springfield, they went to Stockbridge and were reunited with Agrippa, their son/brother, respectively (History of Northampton, Massachusetts; Judd Manuscript).

text.headline: A person was enslaved by Gideon Clark
text.text: A person whose name we do not know was enslaved by Gideon Clark and listed in the Northampton tax records from 1770 (Northampton Town Papers).

text.headline: Lydia Hill admitted to First Church
text.text: Lydia Hill was admitted to First Church in Northampton. The inclusion of a last name suggests that she was a free person at the time, but we do not know for sure (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Rose Binney Had a Conversion Experience
text.text: Rose Binney had a conversion experience and joined a Stockbridge church. Dr. Stephen West, Jonathan Edwards' successor as minister in Stockbridge, wrote about her in later years. He stated that the two discussed her belief that God was angry with her, and that this anger had caused the death of her daughters. He also recounted a story of her milking a cow and seeing her surroundings illuminated by God's light. Since the account is entirely from West's perspective, we cannot know how much of his interpretation of Binney's emotional state is accurate (Article by Dr. Stephen West in Minkema, Jonathan Edwards' Defense of Slavery).

text.headline: Paul indentured to John Wait
text.text: Paul, a child of around seven in Northampton, indentured by John Wait of Southampton. Paul would be an "Apprentice in the art of husbandry." At this time, some towns would petition for court permission to place children of families who were on public support in indentured servitude. This could be done against the will of the parents if the justices agreed. Typically children being indentured for an apprenticeship like Paul were seven years or older, but selectmen did place children under seven in indentured servitude. Paul's mother was named Lydia and may have been Lydia Hill, who was on town support in the 1770s. Paul's indenture is undated (Northampton Overseers of the Poor Records; Judd Manuscript).

text.headline: Abigail Meazon receives Medical Care
text.text: Abigail Meazon, an Native woman, treated by Experience Day, probably for typhus. In the Judd Manuscript, it is written that Day was reiumbursed for watching her, nursing her, and "damage to bed." Day's husband attempted to get Northampton to reimburse him for the expenses of Meazon's care, but the town refused as Meazon was not a resident (she lived in Farmington, Connecticut), and his request was passed on to the state (Judd Manuscript).

text.headline: Dinah died
text.text: Dinah died. We do not know for certain that this is the same Dinah who was enslaved by the Bartlett family and then lived with the Kingsleys, as Dinah was a common name, but since we currently have no conclusive evidence of a second woman named Dinah in Northampton in this period, there is a real possibility that she is the same Dinah who was discussed elsewhere in this project (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Abigail Meazon died
text.text: Abigail Meazon died on October 21, 1772.

text.headline: Phillis taken to Doctor Mather
text.text: Phillis' treatment was mentioned in Elizabeth Porter Phelps' diary. Phelps writes about taking her to "Docter Mather" in Northampton, likely for tuberculosis (Miller, Entangled Lives).

text.headline: Phillis died
text.text: Phillis died. Elizabeth Porter Phelps wrote "Fryday Morning a Little after eight our poor little Phillis left this world. O if she is gone to Bliss this enough pray Father Sanctify it to us all...Satterday We attended her Funeral." While Phillis was ill, her sister Rose was pregnant. After Phillis died, Rose named her newborn daughter Phillis (Miller, Entangled Lives)

text.headline: Agrippa Hull Served in the US Army
text.text: Agrippa Hull enlisted in the fledgling US army and fought in the American Revolution as a private for more than 6 years. He served as an assistant for General Tadeusz Kosciuszko, which may have been where he got his nickname, “Grip” or “Grippy.” He also worked with the Marquis de Lafayette and John Laurens (an abolitionist, but his family were large-scale enslavers) during the Revolution (Nash, Russell, and Hodges, Friends of Liberty).

text.headline: Noah Gomer born
text.text: Noah Willhoughby Gomer was born in Wethersfield, Connecticut, on July 10, 1776. His parents were Quash and Eleanor Smith Gomer. His siblings were named Midar, Tabitha, Catherine, Gomer, Francis, Aaron, Moses, Mary, and Elinor. He was named after his father's first wife's brother, Noah Willhoughby.

text.headline: Amos Hull Jr. serves in US army
text.text: There is a record for an Amos Hull from Hadley who served in several regiments during the American Revolution and deserted either once or twice. He served between 1776 and 1780 (Massachusetts Soldiers and Sailors of the Revolutionary War). We believe there is a good chance that this is Amos Hull Jr.

text.headline: Joseph Maminash II served in the US Army
text.text: Joseph Maminash II served in the military during the American Revolution and is listed in Massachusetts Soldiers and Sailors as follows: Mamanash, Joseph, Hadley. List of men raised to serve in the Continental Army from the 4th Hampshire regiment as returned by Capt. Samuel Cook; residence, Hadley; engaged for town of Hadley; joined Capt. Shay’s co., Col. Putnam’s regt,; term 3 years; also, Private, Capt. Daniel Shays co., Col. Rufus Putnam’s (5th) regt.; Continental Pay accounts for service from Jan. 15, 1777 to Aug, 31, 1778; reported died Aug. 31, 1778;-also, same co. and regt.; return dated Albany, Feb. 9, 1778; mustered by Col. Woodbridge (Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts 1902: 161).

text.headline: Lydia Hill died
text.text: Lydia Hill named in a court record documenting expenses for Hill and her children. The fact that the town was involved in these expenses suggests that Hill was a free woman. Additionally, during the mid 18th century, Massachusetts law required that towns provide "care" or "effective care" for residents by either overseers of the poor or selectmen. Hill died in 1778 from a prolonged illness, perhaps one that caused her to need the town's aid in the first place. Hill is also possibly the mother of Paul, an indentured boy (Judd Manuscript; Northampton Overseers of the Poor Records).

text.headline: Elizabeth Maminash died
text.text: In 1779, then sixty-year-old Elizabeth met an untimely, as-yet-unexplained death. Some traditions say she was stoned to death by a gang of Northampton boys; others that she died in liquor (Dean 1958, Bridgeman 1936, Wilbur 1987). She was buried beside her husband, and her children took up residence among their Native neighbors.

text.headline: Agrippa Hull Established His Life in Stockbridge
text.text: Agrippa Hull returned to Stockbridge, bought a piece of land, worked for Theodore Sedgewick, and helped support his mother, Bathsheba. Sedgewick was a lawyer who represented a previous enslaved person, so Jane Darby came to Sedgewick to ask him to help her gain her freedom from her enslaver, Mr. Ingersoll. She then was freed and she and Hull got married. They had three children, Charlotte, James, and Aseph. Hull also had two other children who passed away, but we do not know their names, when they were born, or if Jane Darby was their mother.  (Nash, Russell, and Hodges, Friends of Liberty).

text.headline: A Male Child Died
text.text: A male child whose name we do not know died. We do not know whether he was enslaved or free, or his cause of death (Register of the deaths in Northampton).

text.headline: Moidore Hillhouse married Rebekah Oliver
text.text: Records from Barre, Massachusetts (in Worcester County), have yielded potential records that could be tied to Moidore of Northampton. These records refer to one Moidore Hillhouse, who married Rebekah Oliver in 1781 in Barre. The Barre record refers to Hillhouse's previous residence as Templeton, Massachusetts, which does not preclude him living in Northampton prior to a residency in Templeton. Hillhouse purchased 30 acres of land in Barre, developed one section of it, and built a log house there.

text.headline: Tony sued Ezra Clapp and won
text.text: Tony sued Ezra Clapp for unlawful imprisonment. Ezra Clapp had enslaved Tony, and though Tony gained his freedom, Clapp attempted to re-enslave him. The case was tried in the courthouse in Northampton. Tony won, and Clapp was ordered to pay him £2. Tony's situation illustrates the fact that despite the ratification of the anti-slavery Massachusetts Constitution in 1780, slavery did not end ("Uncovering the Stories of Black Families in Springfield and Hampden County, Massachusetts, 1650-1865" in Historical Journal of Western Massachusetts, Westfield State University).

text.headline: Clamira baptized
text.text: The Binneys daughter Clamira was baptized in Stockbridge. She was their sixth and youngest child, but only the second who would survive to adulthood (Jones, Stockbridge, Past and Present).

text.headline: Self-emancipated person released from prison
text.text: A self-emancipated person whose name we do not know was mentioned in a newspaper report. He was released from the prison in Northampton by a mob in 1782. The mob stormed the prison to release Samuel Ely, an activist who believed that the Massachusetts constitution was not fair to poor farmers (Trumbull, History of Northampton, Massachusetts).

text.headline: Native man drowned
text.text: First Churches listed that "an Indian fellow drowned at Old Rainbow", but did not give his name. Old Rainbow was a location in the Northampton Meadows (First Church Records)

text.headline: Joab Binney died
text.text: Joab Binney died and left his property to his wife Rose and daughters Tamar and Clamira. Rose Binney may have remarried sometime after this to a man with the surname Salter (Joab Binney Probate Record; Kenneth Minkema, "Jonathan Edwards's Defense of Slavery").

text.headline: Sylvia Church resided with Storrs family
text.text: Sylvia Church lived with the family of Nathan Storrs sometime after she was free. Nathan Storrs was the husband of Sarah Dwight Storrs, who died in 1805. Dwight Storrs was the daughter of Timothy Dwight III and Mary Edwards Dwight, who had enslaved Church (Dwight, The History of the Descendants of John Dwight).

text.headline: Margaret Hull married
text.text: Margaret Hull married Cesar Freeman in Great Barrington, MA. Freeman appears to have been free at the time of their marriage but we do not know if he was born free or was formerly enslaved (Great Barrington Marriages).

text.headline: A Male Child Died
text.text: An Native boy whose name who do not know died at age 16 (First Church Records).

text.headline: A woman died
text.text: An Native woman whose name we do not know died. The church records described her death using these words: "A squaw lying in liquor lay in the sun til she died." (First Church Records)

text.headline: Eunice Hull died
text.text: Eunice Hull, the Native woman married to Amos Hull Jr., died on May 8, 1785. Her death is recorded in Belchertown, so it was likely that Hull moved there (Rev. Justus Forward's Vital Records Books).

text.headline: Hannah Pequin died
text.text: Hannah Pequin died. The record states that "Hannah Pequin an Indian Girl was Executed for the Murder of her Bastard Child." Elizabeth Porter Phelps also wrote about this case in her diary, mentioning that Pequin was "hanged in Northampton for murdering her infant babe" in 1785 (Massachusetts Vital Records; Miller, Entangled Lives).

text.headline: Cornelius Thompson convicted of theft
text.text: Cornelius Thompson, desrcibed as "negro" and a resident of Conway, was convicted of theft in the town of Northampton (Hampshire Gazette).

text.headline: Agrippa Hull Files Suit Against Cesar Freeman
text.text: Agrippa Hull filed a suit in which he claimed that he had been solely responsible for Bathsheba Hull's care, and Freeman, Margaret Hull's husband and Agrippa Hull's brother-in-law, had not contributed. The claim stated that Bathsheba Hull was blind and in a position where she needed to be cared for by her children. (Berkshire Court of Common Pleas)

text.headline: Hull Family Case is dropped
text.text: In January of 1792, court records state that both Agrippa Hull and Cesar Freeman had been called to appear three times with reference to Hull's case against Freeman, but that neither man had appeared. Thus, the case was dropped. The fact that neither appeared suggests that either the family worked out a solution internally, or Bathsheba Hull died during the interim period (Berkshire Court of Common Pleas).

text.headline: Abijah Prince died
text.text: Abijah Prince died. He is commemorated as an enterprising landowner who valued his relationships and had immense perseverance (Holbrook Gerzina, Mr. and Mrs. Prince).

text.headline: Noah Gomer Ran from His Indenture
text.text: Noah Gomer was 19 years old when he decided to run from his indeture with Joseph Hutchens. Gomer's father, Quash, may have placed him in this Indenture due to the economic circumstances of the family, as we know that he did this with some of his other children. Hutchens placed an ad looking to catch Gomer in the Hampshire Gazette as well as other local newspapers.

text.headline: A woman named Sylvia gives birth to a stillborn child
text.text: Church records report that a Black woman named Sylvia who lived in Northampton gave birth to a stillborn child. There were two women named Sylvia in Northampton at the time (Sylvia Church and Sylvia who lived in the home of Joseph Lyman) and it is unclear to which woman the record refers (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Binneys rent out parents' land
text.text: The Binney daughters, Clamira and Tamar, rented out their parents' land, according to a property record. The land had one dwelling house and 25 acres of land.

text.headline: Tamar Binney married and had children
text.text: Tamar Binney married Thomas Kellis and they had two children, Charles B. Kellis, who lived until 1819, and Dr. Joab Kellis, presumably named after Binney's father. Joab Kellis was the first Black physician in Stockbridge (Jones, Stockbridge, Past and Present).

text.headline: Sylvia died
text.text: Sylvia died at nineteen years old. Her death record listed her as "a negro woman living with Gn. Joseph Lyman" (First Churches Records).

text.headline: Susy Wells died
text.text: Susy Wells died. We know almost nothing about Susy Wells, except that she probably died quite young. She was listed as "black girl" in the register of deaths (Register of deaths in Northampton).

text.headline: Polly Palmer died
text.text: Polly Palmer died. She was listed as "black" in the Northampton register of deaths (Register of the deaths in Northampton)

text.headline: Agrippa Hull remarried
text.text: Agrippa Hull's first wife Jane Darby died at some point in the early 1800s. He remarried Margaret Timbrook (or Timebroke), commonly called Peggy. Timbroke was born in Newport, RI in 1789. Timbrook was a gifted chef and she made the wedding cakes for many in Stockbridge. The couple later adopted a daughter named Mary Tilden, who was the biological daughter of a self-emancipated person from NY (Nash, Russell, and Hodges, Friends of Liberty).

text.headline: Sally Maminash joined First Church
text.text: In 1816, Sally Maminash joined First Church along with seventy-six other people, including several other Indians and/or African Americans, and a Nipmuc family named Bakeman. By 1819 large numbers of people had left First Church to join new congregations... Rev. Solomon Williams recorded Sally Maminash’s name on a “List of Church Members 1819 who were living or have not taken a dismissal...” after religious controversy split the congregation (First Church Records, Book 2, 1819:43).

text.headline: Sylvia Church died and buried in Bridge Street Cemetery
text.text: Sylvia Church died at 66 years old. She is one of a few people of color born in the 1700s to be buried in Bridge Street Cemetery in Northampton. She is buried with the Storrs family and her headstone reads “Very few possessed more good qualities than she did.” (Dwight, The History of the Descendants of John Dwight)

text.headline: Clamira Binney married
text.text: Clamira Binney married Nicholas Rich. She would live to be 74 years old. As far as we know, the couple did not have any children.

text.headline: Agrippa Hull sold land
text.text: Agrippa Hull sold off some of his land (he was the largest Black landowner in Stockbridge). He was still a fixture of Stockbridge society, known for his charming personality and being and a source of information about the Revolution (Nash, Russell, and Hodges, Friends of Liberty).

text.headline: Sally Maminash died
text.text: The so-called “last” of Northampton’s Nonotuck Indians, Sally Maminash (alternately spelled Mammanash, Mammanache, etc.), is buried in Northampton’s Bridge Street Cemetery. Her gravestone, situated in the family plot of Warham and Sophia Clapp, reads: “Sally Maminash. The last of the Indians here. A niece of Occum. A Christian. Died in the family of Warham & Sophia Clap. Jan. 3, 1853. Aged 88.”

text.headline: A person was enslaved by Robert Breck
text.text: A person whose name we do not know was enslaved by Robert Breck, as listed in an undated Northampton tax record (Northampton Town Papers). This date range is a guess based on Breck's lifespan

text.headline: Harry servant to Enos Kingsley
text.text: Harry was listed as an "Indian servant" to Enos Kingsley in the Judd Manuscript. Harry's will indicates that he was not enslaved, but rather employed by Enos Kingsley. Harry wished for several of his personal possessions to be distributed to different Northampton men and women (Judd Manuscript).

text.headline: Peter Hired by Joseph Hawley III
text.text: Sylvester Judd (Judd Manuscript) lists Peter as "probably" being an enslaved person. Peter was hired by Joseph Hawley III, though probably not enslaved by him. At the time when Hawley hired him, Peter was a child, but we do not know when he was hired. This would have entailed Hawley using the labor of Peter, but mostly or entirely paying his wages to the person who enslaved Peter (who is also not listed). Hawley lived from 1723-1788, so that is currently the window of time in which we know Peter lived.
